The Buesching mastodon, nicknamed Fred, was found in 1998 outside of Fort Wayne, Indiana. They were able to match that to the profile of a given geographic area, which allowed them to work out where Fred lived and died. Fred died around 13,200 years ago after being gored in the skull by a rival's tusk. Mastodons and elephants display similar migration and mating patterns, so it's possible that these behaviors evolved from one common ancestor before the lines split off.
A new study suggests that nasal sprays and aerosols may pave the way for fewer vaccine-like injections in the future. Aerosols, inhaled via the mouth, have the potential to penetrate deeper into the lungs compared to nasal sprays. Researchers are interested in whether that makes them more efficient. One study found that mice that received an inhaled aerosol vaccine initially had more vaccine droplets in their lungs than those that got a nasal spritz.

Just a warning — all of the “Frontiers” journals are predatory, meaning they require a researcher to pay to get published. In addition, the “Frontiers” group of journals have terrible peer-review, and any articles published in these journals are rarely considered in giving tenure to a researcher who published in them. Finally, the impact factor (which describes how often an average article is cited by other articles) is less than 1.0 for most “Frontiers” journals. Real science requires high quality research published in high impact factor journals, not junk science published in junk journals. You all should know better.
